Award.AwardTitle: Geochemical Calibration of Modern Isopora and Acropora Corals from the Great Barrier Reef and Application to IODP Leg 325 Fossil Corals
Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2010, Integrated Ocean Drilling Project Leg 325 (IODP325) cored drowned fossil reefs off the Great Barrier Reef with the objective of collecting fossil corals that would yield information about past sea levels, ocean temperatures, and ocean chemistry. Massive coral colonies up to ~40 cm in length were the main types of coral recovered during IODP325 with ages spanning the last glacial maximum to the earliest part of the modern warm period (~30,000 to 10,000 years B.P.). Today these corals (Isopora and Acropora species) grow in relatively high-energy environments but little is known about their potential to support paleoceanographic reconstructions since these genera have not been previously used for this purpose.

To address this issue and fully utilize the collected coral cores, this research is designed to develop sampling protocols and calibrations between modern oceanographic temperature and salinity data and skeletal oxygen isotopes and strontium/calcium in modern Isopora and Acropora corals from the Great Barrier Reef. Previously collected modern Isopora and Acropora corals from Heron Island, Myrmidon Reef and New Guinea will be analyzed. In the second part of this work the developed calibrations and sampling protocols will be applied to the fossil corals collected as part of IODP325 to generate more accurate temperature and salinity reconstructions. Because the geochemistry of Isopora and Acropora corals has not been previously calibrated against modern data, this project will directly assist all researchers using IODP325 fossil corals working to answer questions about sea level and sea surface temperature in the climatically important Western Pacific Warm Pool. This work will also provide a sound basis for comparisons with analogous studies using other corals in other localities and habitats (e.g., IODP Leg 310 in Tahiti). The project will support a female graduate student at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for Award Number 1356948

Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) Leg 325 drilling in the Australian Great Barrier Reef recovered a suite of fossil corals of the genus Isopora spanning the time period from 25,000 to 10,000 years B.P. This time period spans the last glacial maximum when sea level as  ~120 m lower than present, across the more recent deglaciation as the global ice melted, to the base of the Holocene, the current interglacial. Since the coral genus Isopora has been relatively unstudied as a paleoclimate-paleoceanographic archive, this project focused on two main tasks: 1.) developing modern calibrations for Isopora coral skeletal strontium content and oxygen stable isotopes to instrumental sea surface temperature and sea surface salinity, and 2.) applying the developed calibrations to the geochemical data generated from IODP 325 fossil Isopora corals.  The calibrations developed as part of our analysis of modern Isopora from Heron Island at the southern end of the Great Barrier Reef are in the range of published Porites coral values and approach the only published values for Isopora. The similarity of our new SST calibrations to common Porites sensitivities supports the use of Isopora in paleoceanographic studies. Application of these modern calibrations to our fossil Isopora coral results from IODP 325 indicates that the surface ocean along the Great Barrier Reef was on average 5-7°C cooler during the last glacial maximum compared to modern conditions. This finding helps place constraints on the magnitude of climate change in this key region in the South Pacific as the Earth experienced warming and ice melting following the last glacial low-stand of sea level.

One female graduate student received training in coral colony processing, sampling and analysis. She also received significant training in the operation and maintenance of stable isotope mass spectrometers. Two female undergraduates received training in basic laboratory procedures (including safety training), and also in coral sample analysis. This included coral slab cleaning, sample path mapping, sample drilling and weighing for analysis. Training also included data checking for QA/QC and in paleoclimate interpretation.  Several lectures on corals and climatic reconstruction was given to high school students at the Lycee French School in Manhattan in spring of 2016 and spring 2017.
